awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Adaptation: ASEE Engineering Deans Gender Equity (EDGE) Initiative
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.  ADVANCE "Adaptation" awards provide support for the adaptation and adoption of evidence-based strategies to academic and non-academic non-profit organizations.

The American Society for Engineering Education's (ASEE's) ADVANCE Adaptation project will engage engineering deans across the country in the Engineering Deans Gender Equity (EDGE) Initiative.  The EDGE Initiative leverages a pledge made by over 200 engineering deans to enhance equity and diversity in engineering started in 2015.  The EDGE project will: 1) reduce institutional and system-level barriers to engineering deans' ability to advance the recruitment, retention, and professional advancement of faculty; and 2) conduct research to determine if reducing impediments promotes deans' capacity to effect positive change for faculty.  The EDGE project will result in the creation of a National Gender Equity Indicators Database; and centralization and dissemination of evidence-based, faculty gender equity leadership resources and strategies. 

The ASEE EDGE Initiative will advance engineering deans' knowledge and understanding for making intentional, research-based changes to promote equity for faculty by addressing barriers to culture change. This work is grounded in three premises: 1) we know a great deal about engineering faculty cultures; 2) engineering faculty culture change is needed and can be accomplished; and 3) deans can provide leadership for changing engineering faculty culture. The EDGE Initiative will advance knowledge through the study of the impact of the EDGE project on engineering deans' actions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) recognizes that to optimize innovation and global competitiveness, the engineering discipline must actively encourage, support, engage, and advance a diverse, equitable, and inclusive community of engineers. The issue of diversity is critical for the ASEE and reflects ASEE?s core values. Currently barriers exist to full engagement in engineering by underrepresented groups such as women, especially women of color. In 2015 ASEE initiated the Deans Diversity Pledge, originally signed by 211 out of what was then 328 (i.e., 64%) engineering deans nationally. One of the four commitments made by dean signatories was to develop and implement  . . . proactive strategies to increase the representation of women and underrepresented minorities in our faculty, . . . a focus that directly aligned with the goals of the National Science Foundation ADVANCE program.  In 2018, the ASEE Engineering Deans Gender Equity (EDGE) Initiative, a 3-year program, was funded through an ADVANCE Adaptation award (# 1760002) (See EDGE Website Homepage image). 

The EDGE target audience was signatories of the ASEE Deans Diversity Pledge.  Recognizing that deans do not operate in isolation, EDGE also encouraged engagement by institutional leaders, engineering chairs/heads, and faculty who serve to motivate and support academic deans. The EDGE Initiative was guided the EDGE National Advisory Board, prestigious group of academic engineering leaders (i.e., Ilene Busch-Vishniac (Board Chair), Cheryl B. Schrader, Brian Blake, Scott Bass, and Orlando Taylor) (See National Advisory Board image.)

The objectives of the EDGE initiative were informed by results of a 2015 ASEE survey to identify gender diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) challenges faced by deans.  These challenges included lack of: national gender DEI benchmarks; centralized, evidence-based, organizational-change resources and tools; limited engineering-specific research-to-practice translation strategies and dean exemplars; and an inadequate pipeline of racially/ethnically diverse women engineering leaders. EDGE objectives and products included:

1. National Benchmarking & Reporting: the EDGE Graphic Explorer Apps compiling national ASEE Profiles data on Women Engineering Tenure-track/Tenured Faculty; and Underrepresented Minority Women Engineering Tenure-track/Tenured Faculty (See Graphic Explorer website image;) as well as additional items included in the Profiles survey to collect information for the ASEE's Diversity Benchmarking Report for Underrepresented Groups in Engineering.

2. Centralized Resources:  the EDGE Change Toolkit, which included:

  • EDGE Change Model
  • EDGE College Self-Assessment Tool
  • EDGE College Self-Assessment Guidebook
  • EDGE Readiness-to-Change Assessment Questionnaire & Resources
  • EDGE Action Checklist (See Poster image) 

3. EDGE Action Strategies & Exemplars: engineering-specific research-to-practice translation strategies and ?evidentiary proofs? of engineering deans successful in gender DEI efforts:

  • EDGE Action Steps Workshops: to increase deans? awareness and adoption of evidence-based gender DEI strategies (See 2019 Action Steps Workshop image.)
  • EDGE Deans? Showcase Webinar Series: to help deans translate research-to-practice, and showcase examples of engineering deans engaged in promising gender DEI.

4. Leadership Development: EDGE-ELATES Fellows & Travel Grants (29), and the iAspire Leadership Academy (16)  provided a total of 45 scholarships focused on leadership development of racially/ethnically diverse women engineers; and support for dean-led teams of 96 people from 19 institutions to participate in the American Association for the Advancement of Science STEMM Equity Achievement?s four-part, monthly learning series: Building Gender Equity in the Academy:  Institutional Strategies for Change.    

Additionally, the EDGE Initiative Conducted Research to determine gender awareness, knowledge and DEI efforts of engineering deans.

Evaluation results indicated that despite the widespread disruptions caused by the COVID19 pandemic and racial justice demonstrations in the middle of the project, the EDGE Initiative has largely succeeded in producing resources and tools aligned with its goals.  Although deans did not engage to a great extent with tools and resources developed by the EDGE team, 357 individuals have been reached through EDGE workshops and webinars. These individuals represent approximately 189 U.S. Colleges and Universities and 3 International Colleges and Universities (of 637 colleges and universities with accredited engineering programs). EDGE events equipped participants with evidence to back up policies and practices they were already promoting to advance gender equity change. Participation in EDGE events helped deans and other college leadership keep gender equity issues top-of mind, provided helpful examples of successful change, and motivated them to continue change efforts. Most deans responding to a dean?s survey reported that allocation of resources to DEI efforts has increased over the past year or more, largely due to the increased focus on racial justice following the murder of George Floyd.  Engagement of deans and other engineering leaders in EDGE events indicated momentum for change that should be captured by other ASEE DEI efforts moving forward.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2022
Modified by: Norman L Fortenberry
